HALL AND SMITH TO
LEAD JUNIOR CLASS
William Purnell Hall;' Jr.,
was re-elected president of the
Junior Class at the meeting
held yesterday. Stewart Smith
was elected vice-president,
while George Gump, Paul Cordish, and Sidney Wolck were
made secretary, treasurer, and
sergeant-at-aims„ respectively.
Hall has been president of
the class since its organization,
while Smith held the office of
secretary in his freshman year—.
The other men are new to class
office.
Nominations for the ,class
officers were held last week,
following the assembly, while
the elections were'held follow.ing yesterday's assembly. A
large percentage of the class
cast its ballot and no difficulty
was experienees1 _in...securing.a.
quorum. The votes were
counted by John Norris, the
official representative of the
Student Council.
The only other business carried on at the meeting was the
election of several newcomers
to the class. The men receiving membership were Gould
and Smith.
The freshman class votes
balloted yesterday also, were
not counted before the NP,WSLETTER went to press.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
THE INTELLECTUAL LIFE
F all the college undergraduates in the United States, only one
per cent are really attempting to prepare for an intellectual
'life, says Mr. Bernard DeVoto in the current issue of Harper's
Magazine. In this article, the author attacks the problem of how superior students can achieve the intellectual life which a university`offers.
In the beginning of his treatise, Mr. DeVoto adve
it s-litva
e'
alsandonment of the fetish of the degree. The degrees of xB.
. o B.S as
well as the higher awards for academic accomplishment, are erely
the trademarks of a standardized product. The colleges, in their wild
scramble to prepare men for professional -training and confer a liberal
educatipn, have set the requirements for the degree in line with standardization.
Mr. DeVoto recognizes, or presumes to recognize, two major
errors in present day educational practice. In the first place, in the
requirements for the degree, the colleges attempt to cover too much*
ground. The second defect is the naive assumption that all fields of
human knowledge are of equal worth.
To illustrate his first point, the author makes the rather exaggerated statement that "nine-tenths of all the college graduates in the
country have studied One modern language and most of them have
studied two, but not one in fifty can read a page.of French or German, still less, tianslate it." Furthermore, the diverse number of subjects which are required for the degree, forces the candidate to abandon every subject in its elementary state in order to hurry on for
some equally'superficial'acquaintance with something else.
•
There are three tools necessary for the pursuit of an intellectual
life, the wrifer arguesHanguage, mathematics and sciences. There
are, he claims, two sorts of modern language instructors in our American- universities. First are the Americans who have learned the
language in this country and, in reality, have little first hand•acquaintance with the tongue. Their pronunciation is usually quite
bad, their feeling toward French or German literature is that of
-- an alien and they are unable to think in the language which they
profess to teach. At the same time, the foreigners which migrate
to our country to teach their native tongues possess numerous defects. They are unable to appreciate the difficulty in learning the
language and they are unable to get into effective rapport with their
students. ,
.
‘Of the sciences, Mr. DeVoto particularly recommends physics,
chemistry and zoology .because in these, he feels the student deals
directly with the basic properties of life and matter—with the real
ity of the objective world. Since thri-nodern world is esSentially a
scientific World, the dominant thinking of today is necessarily scientific in nature. The study of the sciences also teaches impersonal'
thinking. It weeds out the prejudices apd social compulsions which
clutter the average man's thoughts. For only in the laboratory • does
the student learn to see facts and treat them as facts.
For the student who seeks the true intellectual life, the'popular studies, economics, political science, psychology and philosophy,
must be cast into discard. The first two "have little place in the
intellectual life. Their material is as yet capriciously organized, directed largely at wishfulness or fanaticism sit wild assumption and
uncontrolled by scientific method."
Psychology, we are informed, "abounds in pretensions and downright charlatanism.- The student, he advises, should avoid contamination.
-'
Philosophy he describes as a "game:: adding that it is a more
adult diversion than chess. •
For Mr. DeVoto, the true university is really a huge library
where one may wander at random, reading first-this and then that,
without any definite compulsion to study and without any direct
supervision of professors.
-`-r7
While such a concept is a n le and lofty one, we feel that it
is entirely too impractical for the average college to adopt. For the
graduate school such a plan is entirely feasible but for undergraduates, fresh from preparatory schools, without any definite program of study, it is entirely too idealistic. Study must be organized in an orderly fashion and the various subjects properly
correlated in
order for the average undergraduate to ebtain the maximum
'benefit

HALL AND SMITH TO
LEAD JUNIOR CLASS
William Purnell Hall;' Jr.,
was re-elected president of the
Junior Class at the meeting
held yesterday. Stewart Smith
was elected vice-president,
while George Gump, Paul Cordish, and Sidney Wolck were
made secretary, treasurer, and
sergeant-at-aims„ respectively.
Hall has been president of
the class since its organization,
while Smith held the office of
secretary in his freshman year—.
The other men are new to class
office.

EDITORIAL COMMENT
THE INTELLECTUAL LIFE
F all the college undergraduates in the United States, only one
per cent are really attempting to prepare for an intellectual
'life, says Mr. Bernard DeVoto in the current issue of Harper's
Magazine. In this article, the author attacks the problem of how superior students can achieve the intellectual life which a university`offers.
In the beginning of his treatise, Mr. DeVoto adve
it s-litva
e'
alsandonment of the fetish of the degree. The degrees of xB.
. o B.S as
well as the higher awards for academic accomplishment, are erely
the trademarks of a standardized product. The colleges, in their wild
scramble to prepare men for professional -training and confer a liberal
educatipn, have set the requirements for the degree in line with standardization.
Mr. DeVoto recognizes, or presumes to recognize, two major
errors in present day educational practice. In the first place, in the
requirements for the degree, the colleges attempt to cover too much*
ground. The second defect is the naive assumption that all fields of
human knowledge are of equal worth.
To illustrate his first point, the author makes the rather exaggerated statement that "nine-tenths of all the college graduates in the
country have studied One modern language and most of them have
studied two, but not one in fifty can read a page.of French or German, still less, tianslate it." Furthermore, the diverse number of subjects which are required for the degree, forces the candidate to abandon every subject in its elementary state in order to hurry on for
some equally'superficial'acquaintance with something else.
•
There are three tools necessary for the pursuit of an intellectual
life, the wrifer arguesHanguage, mathematics and sciences. There
are, he claims, two sorts of modern language instructors in our American- universities. First are the Americans who have learned the
language in this country and, in reality, have little first hand•acquaintance with the tongue. Their pronunciation is usually quite
bad, their feeling toward French or German literature is that of
-- an alien and they are unable to think in the language which they
profess to teach. At the same time, the foreigners which migrate
to our country to teach their native tongues possess numerous defects. They are unable to appreciate the difficulty in learning the
language and they are unable to get into effective rapport with their
students. ,
.
‘Of the sciences, Mr. DeVoto particularly recommends physics,
chemistry and zoology .because in these, he feels the student deals
directly with the basic properties of life and matter—with the real
ity of the objective world. Since thri-nodern world is esSentially a
scientific World, the dominant thinking of today is necessarily scientific in nature. The study of the sciences also teaches impersonal'
thinking. It weeds out the prejudices apd social compulsions which
clutter the average man's thoughts. For only in the laboratory • does
the student learn to see facts and treat them as facts.
For the student who seeks the true intellectual life, the'popular studies, economics, political science, psychology and philosophy,
must be cast into discard. The first two "have little place in the
intellectual life. Their material is as yet capriciously organized, directed largely at wishfulness or fanaticism sit wild assumption and
uncontrolled by scientific method."
Psychology, we are informed, "abounds in pretensions and downright charlatanism.- The student, he advises, should avoid contamination.
-'
Philosophy he describes as a "game:: adding that it is a more
adult diversion than chess. •
For Mr. DeVoto, the true university is really a huge library
where one may wander at random, reading first-this and then that,
without any definite compulsion to study and without any direct
supervision of professors.
-`-r7
While such a concept is a n le and lofty one, we feel that it
is entirely too impractical for the average college to adopt. For the
graduate school such a plan is entirely feasible but for undergraduates, fresh from preparatory schools, without any definite program of study, it is entirely too idealistic. Study must be organized in an orderly fashion and the various subjects properly
correlated in
order for the average undergraduate to ebtain the maximum
'benefit
